course.subject: MECH
course.name: Engineering Materials II
course.description: MECH 3420, as an extension of MECH 2410, is an advanced course on materials science and engineering offered in this department. This course is composed of three modules, i.e. (1) electrical, thermal, magnetic, and optical properties of general engineering materials; (2) green and smart building materials including ceramics, polymers, advanced insulation and glazing materials; (3) aerospace engineering materials including application of Aluminum alloys, Magnesium alloys, Titanium alloys, as well as superalloys in aerospace structures and engines.

reviews.author: Jacky 01
reviews.title: A 3000-level course that can be easily handled
reviews.comment_content:
This course talks about materials, and it is quite easy to understand and manage. It doesn't involve complex calculation, and no calculus is presented in the calculation. Most of the content are about theory. So it is a quite easy course, suitable for those who are not talented in Math. Some content is related to Mech2410, but not much is required. So feel comfortable to take the course even if you forgot all the content from Mech2410. The hardest chapter is probably ch.6 ceramics, which you need to read both polling, tutorial notes and lecture notes to understand. But overall, it is still not very hard.

Chapter 1-Introductionto Engineering Materials II
Chapter 2-Electrical properties of engineering materials
Chapter 3-Thermal properties of engineering materials
Chapter 4-Magnetic properties of engineering materials
Chapter 5-Optical properties of engineering materials
Chapter 6-Ceramics –crystal structures, properties, and fabrications
Chapter 7 -Polymers –structures, properties, synthesis, and applications
Chapter  8 -Smart Insulation Materials for Buildings
Chapter 9-Understanding Aerospace Materials
Chapter 10-Aluminum Alloys and Magnesium Alloys for Aerospace Structures
Chapter 11-Titanium Alloys for Aerospace Structures and Engines
Chapter 12-Superalloys for Gas Turbine Engines
Chapter 13–Materials degradation and Non-destructive Monitoring of Aerospace materials
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is good. Prof. Tao Hong also taught me Mech2410. She explain clearly for the content. And even if you missed some of the content, you can still refer to lecture notes without any difficulties. I think the lecture notes are quite well made that it explain the concept clearly. After each lesson, there will be a polling section consist of 4 question. The polling are just for the professor to know how much of the content you understand. It will not be counted toward your grade or for taking attendance. So feel free to make mistake. But it is still a good opportunity for you to check your concept. Also, the professor is very kind. During the end of semester, we has one last quiz in the study break, but the deadline conflicts with the progress report presentation of FYP. So we ask whether she can postpone the deadline, and she did! She gave us 2 extra day for the quiz, so nice!

The tutorial, however, are quite boring. The TA just simply read out the tutorial notes. However, the tutorial notes are well made as well, so you must read and try the question in the notes even if you don't want to attend the tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
This course has 3 assignment, 6 quiz, mid-term and final exam. The assignment format are similar to mech2410 which can be done in hours. The 6 quiz are on canvas. They consist of MC question, fill in the blank and simple calculation. The calculation won't be hard.

Assignment (total 3): 15%
Online quiz (total 6): 24%
Mid-term exam: 25%
Final exam: 36%

The grading is quite evenly distributed, so even if you fail to get a good score in one of them, you still have a chance to ace in other part to get a decent grade. However, since the course content is not hard, and the mid-term and final exam are even more easier, the mean are relative high. The means are:

Assignment: 269.6/300 (89.9%)
Quiz: 500/600 (83.3%)
Mid-term: 78.8%
Final exam: 72.5%
Overall: 79.28%

The mid-term has 20 MC questions and 4 short answer question. It last for 80mins. The coverage is ch.1-5. The MC question are quite easy. And short answer do not involve complex calculation as well. So overall, the mid-term is easy. In fact, it is even easier than assignment and quiz. You even has time remain to double check each question.

For final exam, it has 30 MC questions and 4 short answer which last for 2 hours. The coverage is ch.6-13. It is quite easy as well. It is also easier than assignment and quiz. Most of the question don't involve calculation. If they do, they can be done in short period amount of time.

My grade:
Assignment 1: 100/100
Assignment 2: 100/100
Assignment 3: 99/100

Quiz 1: 100/100
Quiz 2: 85/100
Quiz 3: 75/100
Quiz 4: 100/100
Quiz 5: 100/100
Quiz 6: 100/100

Mid-term: 89/100
Final exam: 88/100
Overall: 91.28%

Final grade: A+
Quite good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: There are not much workload. The 3 assignment are not hard to do. And the time given for the assignment is quite long. For the quiz, you need to study hard since the weighting is similar to mid-term. It usually consist of 8-10 question, includes MC question, fill in the blank and simple calculation. It will be automatically graded. The quiz questions are very similar to the mid-term and final exam, I think some of them are the same. So you should take a screen shot for each question for revision when doing the quiz since the solution will note be shown after you submitted. To be noticed that each quiz only has 20mins to do, and you cannot return to the previous question once you go to the next question. So you need to control your time. The quiz are usually due in 4 days after posted on canvas.

reviews.author: GU
reviews.title: Forget about life
reviews.comment_content:
Similar to material one but with more in depth knowledge in stuff like composites and organic materials.

Don't depend on the professor though. So please make sure you either read the book or get the Charles Kwan's notes. Charles' notes are apparently a lot better. Sadly he left, and even sadder Sherry Chen is taking over this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This prof is a failure in teaching, she doesn't point out the important parts in the notes. Actually, the notes don't have any useful information, and turns out to be useless when you revise for midterms or finals.
Also, she doesn't explain many things, and assume that all her students have already PhD level of knowledge.
reviews.comment_grading:
It was ok, I guess this is the only thing that is fine about this course.

She might change the grading scheme in the middle. Please be aware of it.

Since you are not anymore required to take this course, and had the patience to read till here, my warm suggestion is not to take the course unless you are 150% sure you want to do material related stuff in the future.
reviews.comment_workload:
She gives about 1 homework each week and make sure you ask who came up with the homework. If it is from Sherry Chen, then god bless you. The TAs are overall nice with the homework and you can most of the time find the solutions online.

What is awful about this course is that Sherry Chen, as a very random professor, might come up with some "practical" essay homework to help you understand the materials better. Of course it was not in the syllabus at the beginning of the semester. But as she says: "whatever".

reviews.author: Alex_3766
reviews.title: Would not take if I could go back in time
reviews.comment_content: If you like material I, like some science freak, then this course's material would be interesting to you. Will have some review on Material I and crystal structure. It teaches composite material, ceramic, and some quantum knowledge at last.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Sherry is a kind prof who usually do researches, but teaches...
She does not provide a clear goal for you, so you would feel like taking not much from the course.
I felt really frustrated when Sherry said the materials taught in the whole semester was wrong as reality is not ideal just before our final exam. So, what am I suppose to answer in the exam?
I used to love material I as I am taught by Charles (took A-), so I took material II, which turns out to be horrible due to this professor.
reviews.comment_grading:
Normal grade. No comment.
Grade is already not important as you could not learn from the course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not much. Just homeworks like every weeks and a short essay pop up randomly just before the end of semester.
But due to poor teaching, the workload for self study is humongous.

reviews.author: potat0
reviews.comment_content:
Continuation of MECH 2410 syllabus, but with more diverse covering, useful course for people interested in materials and design.
Uses the same textbook.

- Atomic structure and crystallography review
- Ceramics
- Polymers
- Composites
- Corrosion and degradation
- Electrical properties
- Thermal properties
reviews.comment_teaching:
Poor organisation, poor lecturing, poor notes, very late grading, inconsistent and vague as to what is tested in exams, can be disrespectful to students and TAs alike.
Some inconsistency between teaching notes and textbook, and some confusion n the formulas as well
reviews.comment_grading:
40% homework and essay
20% Midterm
40% final (cumulative)
- closed book , no cheat sheet but formula sheet given on the exam.
- Grading is not too harsh but you'll have to figure out what the prof expects from you early on.
Studying from the textbook is much more useful than using lecture notes. Exam and class coverage are significantly different. Depending on who prepares the homework questions (prof or TAs) , you might be able to find answers online but only very detailed answers get full marks
reviews.comment_workload:
not much workload
5 homeworks (every 2 weeks or so)
1 Essay (together with the last homework)
